awd_titl_txt: Accelerated Chemistry In Aerosol Droplets Relevant To The Atmosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry supports Professor Murray Johnston of the University of Delaware to investigate chemical reactions in aerosol droplets that may contribute to formation of organic particulate matter in the atmosphere. The main health impacts of air pollution arise from ozone and particulate matter. This project studies how water in airborne particles can assist formation of organic particulate matter from volatile organic compounds in ways that are not readily predicted by studying chemical reactions in bulk aqueous solution.  This project also contributes to the development of the scientific workforce through graduate student training in an environment that encourages multidisciplinary innovation and public outreach.  
 
An aerosol flow reactor is used to study chemical reactions on the surface of aqueous ammonium sulfate droplets that combine two volatile monomer reactants to give a nonvolatile dimer product.  These reactions include aldehyde-aldehyde reactions to produce an aldol, aldehyde-alcohol reaction to produce a hemiacetal, and alcohol-acid reaction to produce an ester.  The reactor system has the ability to precisely control initial droplet size and composition including water content, ionic strength and acidity.  Systematic control of these variables provides insight into reaction mechanisms.  Intermediates and products of the reactions are characterized and, where possible, quantified with a variety of online mass spectrometry methods. These methods include elemental analysis with the nano aerosol mass spectrometer, which gives a measure of droplet acidity based on the nitrogen-to-sulfur mole ratio, and molecular analysis with droplet assisted ionization and extractive electrospray ionization.  Students supported by the project are broadly trained in environmental chemistry, analytical chemistry and nanoscience.  They bring environmental topics to the attention of scientists and non-scientists alike through various outreach events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigated how molecular coupling reactions in aerosol particles containing water affect growth and composition of particles smaller than 100 nm in diameter.  Growth of particles in this size range contributes to the production of cloud condensation nuclei in the atmosphere, which can significantly impact global climate.  Several reaction types were studied as a function of particle size, water content, inorganic salt composition, and the organic precursors involved in the coupling chemistry.  To enable this work, we had to develop and apply methods for particle analysis including online mass spectrometry with droplet assisted ionization (molecular analysis), offline mass spectrometry with liquid chromatography – high resolution mass spectrometry (molecular analysis), and laser induced plasma (elemental analysis).  The overall goal was to determine the types of reactions and experimental conditions that are able to enhance product formation in droplets over that predicted from bulk solution measurements.  

 

After developing the analytical methods, we used them to study an exemplar reaction that is known to be accelerated in droplets: derivatization of carbonyl functionalities in secondary organic aerosol by Girard’s T reagent.  The reaction rate constant in droplets was determined and found to be four orders of magnitude faster than the corresponding reaction rate in bulk solution.  Factors such as salts in solution and the relative humidity of the surrounding air were investigated for their effect on droplet reactivity.  The droplet size dependence of this reaction for droplets in the 20-200 nm diameter range showed that product formation increased with decreasing droplet size.  The results indicate that accelerated reactions such as this will have the greatest impact on the smallest particles in the atmosphere.  

 

Subsequently, we used the same general approach to study atmospherically relevant particle growth processes.  In this work, we quantitatively studied the effect of particulate water, either on the surface or within the bulk of a seed particle, on the growth of seed particles by secondary organic aerosol formation, where an organic molecule in the gas phase is oxidized by ozone to give products that grow the particles.  Four types of seed particles were investigated – freshly formed organic particles produced by alpha-pinene ozonolysis that should have no water on the surface or in the bulk, solid ammonium sulfate particles that have water on the particle surface, aqueous ammonium sulfate seed particles that have water throughout the particles, and aqueous ammonium bisulfate seed particles that have water in the bulk.  For particle growth by SOA formation from alpha-pinene ozonolysis, we found that organic seed particles gave the least growth, solid ammonium sulfate particles (water on the surface) gave somewhat higher growth, and aqueous ammonium sulfate particles (water throughout the particle) gave the highest growth.  Similar enhancements were observed for SOA formation from isoprene ozonolysis.  Molecular composition analysis suggested that these differences arise from two water mediated processes: oligomer formation where two or more organic molecules combine to make one large molecule, and organosulfate formation where dissolved salt ions combine with organic molecules to give a product. Overall, growth was found to vary by more than 4x across the reaction conditions studied. The results highlight the crucial role that seed particle characteristics, specifically water content, play in determining particle growth rates in a size range relevant to formation of cloud condensation nuclei.
